The Crist Electric Generating Plant is located at 11999 Pate Road, Escambia County, Pensacola, FL, has six electric generating units (four coal fired and two gas fired), and is operated by Gulf Power Company, a subsidiary of the Southern Company.

Employee safety and health is a fundamental value of Gulf Power and the Southern Company.  It is the policy of this facility to provide and maintain safe working conditions and to operate and manage facilities in a manner that protects the environment and meets or surpasses all applicable Federal, State, and local environmental regulations.  Plant Crist has a safety program designed to ensure that employees and contractors are working in a safe environment.  The program includes training, operating and maintenance procedures, as well as auditing and incident investigation programs. 

Plant Crist will have one process covered by the Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations, 40 CFR Part 68, as a Program 3 process.  Anhydrous ammonia will be stored on site in two identical 20,500 gallon vessels for use as part of the Selective Catalytic Reduction system (SCR) on Unit 7 to control nitrogen oxide emissions from burning low sulfur coal.  

The worst case ammonia release scenario was defined as the release of the largest single vessel occurring over a 10 minute time period. The Degdis model predicted that the ammonia would travel 2.8 miles before reaching its endpoint.  The 2000 Census data predicted that 14,423 would be affected by a worse case ammonia release.  The alternative release scenario used for the modeling was as follows: a valve fault causing three pressure relief valves to open fully and release ammonia at a rate of 3.7 kg/s for approximately one minute followed by a release resulting from improper shutting, causing the leak to continue at  0.037kg/s for 59 minutes.  The model predicted that the ammonia would travel 0.12 miles before it reached its endpoint.  The alternative release scenario would affect no off-site pe

rsons.

Crist Plant has developed an emergency response plan that complies with 29 CFR 1910.38 to protect the public health and the environment.  The plan includes procedures for notifying the public about accidental releases, procedures for the use and maintenance of response equipment, employee training, and procedures to review and update the plan.  Emergency notification will be made by calling 911 to notify Escambia County Haz Mat teams.
